natural solution: To investigate this summation, we can start by looking at the first terms: $1 + 1 + (2!) \times 2 = 2 + (2!) \times 2 = 6 = 3!$.

Thus, adding the next term, $6 + (3!) \times 3 = 3! + (3!) \times 3 = 4 \times 3! = 24 = 4!$. Indeed, we see from the identity $$n! + (n!) \times n = (n+1) \times n! = (n+1)!$$that the sum will be equal to $51!$.
The largest prime number to divide this quantity will be the largest prime number less than or equal to $51$, which is $\boxed{47}$.
